This is an articulated camera mount for the Raspberry Pi's camera. I leveraged the wonderful joints from TinkerPlay, and built a system that should allow you to put as many joints in your mount as you'd like. This is a (spiritual) remix of thing:587765; most of the parts are recreated from scratch. The only thing I reused was the case for the camera, and pieces of the camera bracket. Updates:
  • 01/17/16: Added a through hole to frame_clip.stl so you can tie off elastic to help the arm articulate.
  • 12/31/15: Removed the Work in Progress flag, as this has been working so well, there's not much more work left to do.
  • 07/07/15: Added an improved 8020 clip that clips internally, as opposed to externally. I renamed the previous clip to external_frame_clip.stl
  • 04/23/15: I've printed this, and it works wonderfully! Please, try it, and give me some feedback!

Print one of everything, except the arm_joint.stl file, which you will want several. I suggest starting with three, and printing more if you need them. Assembly is pretty simple. The camera presses into the case_front.stl, and case_back.stl just snaps into the back. You then put two M3 screws/nuts through the holes on the side, and camera_bracket.stl. From there, just snap in as many arm_join.stl pieces as you need, and clip it to the frame! Note: One suggestion is to get some rubber, either from a hair tie or a rubber band, and tie a not in one end, run it through the joints, and then tie it off on the other end, after pulling it tight. This just helps the joints pull against each other and makes it easier to articulate.

comments.text: I printed your new parts in PLA this morning, and they turned out well on the first attempt. According to Simplify3D, the meshes aren't manifold, though. The ball-and-socket joints were very tight, but they're workable, and could easily be sanded down a little. My only issue, is that the 20mm extrusion clip is a bit too inflexible around the corners, and appears to have developed stress cracks after installation.

This is a sopranino recorder with standard (English) recorder fingering. Unlike recorders of the baroque era onwards, this recorder has a straight bore. The sound is breathy and piercing.

Updated 18/5/2013: The nose is now a separate piece, preventing the flat inside surface from sagging. This design should now produce a clear tone after welding together, with no extra work. This instrument is intended to be printed in ABS then welded together using acetone. Choose the number of pieces based on the maximum printing height of your printer and what it can print without tipping the part over: full instrument - 237mm
3 piece - 155mm
4 piece - 110mm
5 piece - 74mm
6 piece - 60mm I recommend the 5 piece version, if possible. I suggest printing with 100% infill. Due to the tallness of the pieces, they have a tendency to come loose while printing. This has been less of a problem since I switched from kapton tap to blue masking tape as a base material. To weld two pieces together, dip the two ends you are going to join in acetone for 20 seconds or so, then smoosh them together firmly. Gloves, glasses, and good ventilation would be a good idea while doing this. This instrument was designed using the open source package Demakein:
http://www.logarithmic.net/pfh/design

title: Remote Driven Extruder, not a bowden

description.text:
This is a very experimental remote driven extruder to get the speed of a bowden with the accuracy of a traditional extruder, i have not tested as of yet but everything assembled correclty in inventor assembly as shown so I'm putting this up for those who want a crack at it until i can get to my printer, also i lowered the motor mount and idler for the belt to give better clearance. most parts will need to be rotated and/or dropped to bed level. I've included all ipt's for inventor, to adapt this to another shaft you would need to change the little_gear insert and coupling all else would remain with a slight possibility of needing to enlarge the hole for the shaft to pass through in the extruder body if is much larger but remember the 608 only has a 8mm internal diamater so that would be the limit, the big gear is a massive file and I won't be uploading the ipt but it shouldn't be needed EDIT- added a pic showing new belt clearance at full z height with the lowered belt position also puts the belt more inline with the x carriage on the bottom so less distortion meaning a smoother ride on the x-axis
EDIT 2- just realized the export on the stl's was in cm not mm so they where 10 times to small, new stls uploaded inspired by http://garyhodgson.com/reprap/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/Prusa-Mendel-Off-Carriage-Extruder-PoC-MattRobertsCompactExtruder.png

the only additonal hardware is a 608 skate bearing and a vex robotics square shaft 12 inches long(might be able to pull one from an old printer if its the same size) print one of everything and 2 couplings assemble as seen in image if you can't see the insert, it goes in the bearing on the x-end to hold the sqaure shaft as i don't know the height of all carriages the extruder has slotted holes for fine tuning the alignment i used gregs x-carraige in the design

title: OpenPilot Atom & Nano 30.5 mm mount adapter

description.text:
This adapter creates a nice surface to mount OpenPilot Atom or Revolution Nano. You can use double sided tape to mount it, or alternatively some vibration damping material of your choice.  
Small UBECs fit under the mount. You can also conveniently route wires under it. I have eBay "DC-DC 4.5V-28V to 0.8V-20V Step Down Module" under the adapter, tuned to 5V and locked with a drop of CA glue.  
Not in optimal print orientation. Print with support.

author: jkoljo

title: Customizable Dual Angle Stop Motion Stand for iPad, etc.

description.text: This stand is designed to hold an iPad or other tablet for the purpose of stop motion animation. One side of the stand has a very slight angle and is for close-up shooting with the camera positioned on the bottom. The other side has a larger angle for medium-distance shooting with the camera positioned on the top. Note: The middle groove looks like a third slot, but it is not intended to be. A future version will fix this confusion. This design has been tested with iPad Air 2 and there is an STL file pre-customized for that thickness. For other devices or to adjust the angle of repose on either side, an OpenSCAD file with easily changeable variables is included. Read the story behind the thing.

I suggest using a product like gripper pads on the bottom to keep the stand from moving around while animating.

  • If downloading an STL file preconfigured for your device, you should be able to just print. I've been using 20-25% infill for a slightly sturdier stand.

  • If downloading the .scad file for customization, the key variables that can be changed per-side are:
    • gAngleOfRepose - The number of degrees that the stand tilts the tablet forward.
    • gMaterialThickness - This is the thickness of your device, or whatever you are holding in the stand, measured in mm. An extra .1 or .2 mm ensures you'll be able to slide the device in without too much resistance. Also, I have found that the larger the angle of repose you use, the more extra thickness you should add to ensure that the tablet still slides in smoothly.

title: Surface Mount (SMT) Tweezer Probe Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This set of instructions will show you how to make a set of surface mount tweezers that act as electrical probes. This will allow you to easy measure the value of surface mount components either in circuit, or out of circuit. 
Each leg of the tweezers is one electrical contact. Normally these are used with digital multi-meters (DMM), but can also be used with an oscilloscope by using a different connector.

• Print out two copies of the "SMT Tweezers.stl" file on a 3D printer

  • Cut a strip of metal which is 0.80mm thick x 6.3mm wide and 60 mm long (you can get the width and thickness as standard stock). This will form the electrical contacts.

  • Clip one end of the metal down so that it comes to a point as shown in the photograph. You don't need to get this perfect yet we'll adjust it later. Also sand one side of each point so that it has a gradual taper. This will allow it to make better contact when the metal is bent slightly.

  • Attach the electrical contacts from a coax (I used RG-174) to each of the metal strips. Keep the solder contacts small so that they will fit into the gap at the top of the plastic "V". You can also widen the gap slightly if needed.

  • Insert the metal strips, with the wires attached, into the slots in the center of each leg of the plastic "V". The wire should exit out the opening at the intersection of the legs. See the photo for how the assembly should look at this point.

  • Slide the second plastic "V" over the top of the exposed metal strips. The whole assembly should now be able to be pressed together.

  • Once you have a good fit open the two halves back up and insert a small amount of glue to hold everything together. You can also add some glue in the section with the electrical connections to serve as a strain relief.

  • Finally bend the tips together a bit, and set the gap that you would like when the tweezers are open. Now close them and make sure the tips touch. You may need to adjust the bend angle at this point.

  • Finally with the tips closed use a dremel tool or file to shape the tips into a clean point when they are touching.

  • Add a small loop of red and black shrink tube to each metal tip, this will identify the polarity of the leg when you hook it up. The black ring should go on the tip attached to the shield if you are using coax cable.

  • Attach whatever connector you need to the other end of the wire. (Banana plugs for a DMM, BNC for a scope). When you have completed the assembly the tweezers should appear as shown in the photos.

description.text: A device for Macro Focus Stacking photography, capable of holding heavy professional cams like Nikon D3X, D4S etc. 25 frames/mm standard resolution ... (Stepper Motor's resolution : 200 steps/8 mm)

Hi, this is a focus stacker i made for my Nikon cameras and Manfrotto and Kirk gears. Resolution may be as high as 400 frames/mm which may be useful at 25x or more magnification levels. It can carry cameras and lenses up to 4 Kg. Kirk Arca Swiss plate holder at the top and the Manfrotto Fluid Video Head plate at the bottom and the stepper motor are the most expensive parts, overall cost should be around $250.- or little less depending on the country .. Here is the parts list ; http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/761525-REG/Manfrotto_509PLONG_509PLONG_Quick_Release_Plate_for.html
http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/555493-REG/Kirk_QRC_3_0_QRC_3_Quick_Release_Clamp.html
http://www.pbclinear.com/FMT-Metric-Thin-Wall-Linear-Plain-Bearings
http://medias.schaeffler.de/medias/en!hp.ec.br.pr/BK*BK0810
https://www.pololu.com/product/1401
http://www.pbclinear.com/Linear-Shafting---RC60-Steel-Stainless-Steel-and-Ceramic-Coated-Lightweight-Aluminum
http://www.amazon.com/SHF12-Linear-Shaft-Support-shaft/dp/B00AJA1EYW
https://www.pololu.com/product/2268 the rest is nuts and bolts.. Stepper motor comes with 28 cm lead screw, you have to cut 12.8 cm of it
ceramic coated aluminium bars with thin wall linear bearings over them provide an excellent slide and linearity
I use Kirk Quick release clamp since all my cameras have Kirk L-Plates attached so i can use them either in horizontal or vertical position easily
Manfrotto video plate at the bottom provides a very strong hold and able to carry very heavy loads, also compatible with many of the fluid video heads
Since this device is designed for macro focus stacking it may not be necessary to include the two µswitches at the beginning and the end of the travelling area, many small things or creatures require 25 or 50 frames / mm resolution and they are rarely bigger than one cm, so i generally use the middle area of the 13.5 cm max slide distance. Omitting µswitches also eliminates the need of printing parts FS5 and FS6 since they are used for for the cables of µSwitches.. I printed the device in my Makerbot Replicator 2 using fine resolution for FS1, FS2, FS3, FS4 ..
I include the x3g files so that Replicator 2 owners may directly feed their machine with the printing code ..

This is a free standing Wiimote holder that can be used with a tripod. I've used this a few times to set up Johnny Chung Lee's Wiimote whiteboard with a projector to do a number of fun things. It's a little tall, but I wanted to be able to use the Wiimote in setups were what it was tracking happened to be on the ceiling or floor without having to use a tripod. Johnny Chung Lee's Wiimote projects:
http://johnnylee.net/projects/wii/ Just a quick note when using with a tripod - some tripod fasteners are not long enough to go through the acrylic and fasten securely with a 1/4" nut, unfortunately. My tripod just barely works with this setup.

All the laser cut pieces are 1/8" acrylic. The provided vector files are already optimized a bit for laser cutting. Unfortunately it doesn't quite fit on the smallest available Ponoko material blank, but with a little tweaking, you may be able to get it to fit (if you go the next size up you can fit 4 on a sheet).
See the attached PDF for details on assembly and feel free to contact me if you'd like a set of laser cut parts for this project.

This is a belt idler guide for 13mm bearring that will fit on most 3d printer. I found out that the belt tends to grind on the edge of the tensioner/idler and this is not a good idea to leave it grinding at the edge. It might break the belt one day and the benefits of adding this little friend you will get smoother and lighter motion while lessening the friction caused by the grinding at the edge  
The plastic were grinded on the edge of the bearing holder, it might generate a lot of plastic particles

Printed mine with these parameters ABS
layer 0.1
bed 110c
extruder 230
speed 20mm

This is a spreadsheet that will generate a list of points for half a gear tooth (image shows CAD result for 3 teeth) depending on the number of teeth, pressure angle and profile offset. http://school.mech.uwa.edu.au/~dwright/DANotes/gears/appendices.pdf (Appendix B)
and:
http://school.mech.uwa.edu.au/~dwright/DANotes/gears/generation/generation.html#top I've given up on trying to code this in any way.

Knob for 5mm shaft stepper motors with a flatted shaft.  
I had a few gripes with the stock EZStruder knob (which looks like a gear) in that it was too small of a diameter, was too close to the motor and wasn't easy to tell how fast the motor was turning by watching the knob.  
So I put this together with a larger diameter, longer body and an eccentric hole pattern that makes it super easy to judge rotational speeds.  
Should probably drill & tap for a setscrew, the flat doesn't stand up to much abuse (see blue knob in photo).

Took the original pot and made it smaller and stretched the X axis a bit.  Idea was to make it fit on a windowsill a bit better.  
The red print is on HIPS medium quality.  Lego is for scale...

I re-arranged the Rhino Like Transport by Da5id into something a bit easier to print and assemble.  The tracks are built in, the top plate is stretched vertically just a bit for better detail (in my opinion.) I chopped most of the center out of the thing to speed up printing and reduce waste.   
Edit: I decided to mark it as a work in progress as everytime I look at the thing, I see places it could be improved.  
Edit: Three of the pieces are currently sized wrong. I have no idea how that happened since the fully assembled version pictured used what I thought were the same parts. Maybe I uploaded the wrong files.  The left and right exhaust are about 4mm too wide (easily fixed with an Xacto Knife or a rotary tool) and the rear door piece is too tall, but isn't noticeable when assembled.  I'll update the files when I figure out what went wrong.

description.text: This is one part of a microphone clip for the Thomann t.bone SC300 microphone. It broke 2 years ago and I always wanted to buy a spare part, but never found the time. Now I don't need to buy it anymore, since I have openSCAD and some 3D-printers :) It might also work for other microphones, but I only tested it with the t.bone SC300. Some code was taken from here: http://www.iheartrobotics.com/2011/02/openscad-tip-round-2-of-3.html

• If you have a different mic: change the design in the .scad file (using openSCAD)

  • Print it (I used a RepRap Prusa Mendel for the preview and a Dimension Elite for the final design)

  • Screw it to the other part of the microphone clip. The other part can be seen in the last picture - it usually doesn't break and it has another screw that connects the clip to your mic stand.

title: Filament hook mount for PrintrBot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My first 3D printed design, and a standard rite of passage -- a filament hook for my printer.  
Unlike many of the ones I see on here, I wanted one where I could attach a bolt or additional mount of my choosing, so this just provides a 1/4" hole for a long bolt.  
It fits snugly enough that I had to label it "not a handle", lest someone try to carry off the printer with it...

Print upside down.  
Stick on top of printer.  
Add bolt.  
Hang filament.  
Move on with your life.

title: Mini omni wheel prototype
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I REDESIGNED THIS IN OPENSCAD -- UPDATES WILL BE POSTED ON THE NEW THING PAGE. This is my attempt to remix Arcwave's O-ring based omni wheel with mbbackus's split-ring one. Basically, Arcwave's O-ring idea is great for traction, but the spinners are on plastic axles in a plastic housing, so the rolling friction seems bad. mbbackus's use of a split ring to provide the axle is awesome, but the spinners he uses are washers, so it seems like traction would suffer. Lastly, I don't need them to be as big as either design, and I had 1.5" split rings on hand, so mine are also tiny, and use 8mm ID O-rings instead of 1/2" ones. I haven't gotten the O-rings in yet, so right now they're partly untested. The wheel hub halves and spinners do indeed print and go together, but I haven't confirmed that the spinners will still work well with O-rings, and I haven't been able to test overall functionality. You're welcome to use them, but they might suck.

PRINT the following per wheel
  • (2x) hub halves*

  • (12x) spinners

  • I've also included an STL for one full hub, but I'm not sure how you'd get a split ring on it when it's whole.

OBTAIN the following per wheel:
  • (1x) 1.5" split ring (key ring)
  • (12x) 13mm OD / 8mm ID / 3mm thick rubber O-ring (search on ebay, they're sold in the 100s for tattoo places, since they're used in piercings).
  • Something to attach the two hub halves (screws, glue, etc.)

DO this stuff:
  • Wrap each spinner with a rubber O-ring.
  • Put the 12 spinners onto the split ring as you would a key.
  • Sandwich two hub halves into the split ring, maneuvering the spinners into the open slots.
  • For any spinners that don't spin freely, take them back off and widen the hole with a round file, drill bit, or you can even strip it wider with a screw.
  • Attach to robot, drive every direction ever.

comments.text: I decided to learn OpenSCAD, so I redesigned this -- I'll be posting updates on the new thing page for it here.

author: CMPresby

title: Ninjaflex Drive Mod for Mk8 V7 Extruder upgrade

description.text:
Modified whpthomas' excellent Replicator 2 Extruder Upgrade thing: (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42250) to add
Support for flexible filament for the entire path to the exgtruder
Including a conic guide to the aluminum block, and a bump out for the gap in the drive gear, to prevent NinjaSuck. This preserves the rest of the design, including the clever built in support.

Print solid, left and right versions attached.  Add the arms and enjoy the awesomeness.  
This mod has been working like a champ now, printing Ninjaflex parts.  
Depending on how well your printer is tuned, you might need to drill out the holes, slightly.  You want a close fit, but not too tight on the filament.  
Enjoy

comments.text: Credit where due, you and whpthomas have made a thing of beauty here.  I've attempted to make many other drive blocks like this and haven't had any come out where I immediately thought "This is going to work..." and none of them have...

author: DrazzticAction

description.text: This is a plastic, white m&m that I made using the makerbot. It is one inch by one inch.

I made a file on Adobe Inventor and extruded the circle and the m. I looked up what font is used on m&ms and used it. I converted my document into an STL file to be used for the makerbot. Next, I put it on a flashdrive and plugged it into the makerbot. After it finished preheating I pressed build and it created my object.

title: Repaired Raspberry Pi B+ Retro Case. Repaired original files, made vents larger.

description.text:
The original base unit has several holes and multiple shells. I removed the extraneous geometry to create a true solid, also ran the finished product through netfabb just in case.   
I enlarged the vent slots slightly, this should help with overclocking, especially since there are no air inlet holes on the bottom or sides.

These antilash straps are designed to slip over the 'fork' ends of the Rostock Max V2 arms (they may work on the v1 too.. haven't tried) to reduce lash.  As such, they should be printed from Ninjaflex or a similar TPE material.

This Thing is a replacement for the original fragile engine cowling that comes with the GWS Pico Tiger Moth.  Even at 0.5 mm thick the ABS shell is surprisingly strong. It was very simple to model in OpenSCAD using two conical cylinders and the hull command.

Printed on a Replicator 1 Dual with RepG039-Sailfish at 80/160 mm/s, 10% infill, no raft.  By printing directly onto the HBP the front of the cowling is surprisingly flat and smooth.  Feel free to hack the OpenSCAD to suit your particular aircraft.

description.text:
This was generated using Scherk-Collins Sculpture Generator here: http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~sequin/SCULPTS/scherk.html The form here is a toroidal warp and is printable directly from the generator with a little clean up in Sketchup. The generator can do some other cool things too though so do play around. Notes on the generator:
  • Try not to use a high resolution or the STL will take ages to process and clean.
  • When saving out a file you have to manually add the .stl after your chosen name or it just saves as a generic file.
  • I have nothing to do with the generator or its development, I have used it before to create cool sculptures for 3D renderings and now that I have a 3D extruder i'm all over it again.

Download
Scale
Center
Generate
Print My black version was printed on a ToM stepstruder with the new 0.4mm nozzle and 1.75mm filament. There were some very small overhang loops but it overcame these and a small cleanup with a knife afterwards sorted them out.

This is a creative coin like object with a famous quote from the Dark Knight trilogy and a pop out Dark Knight logo!

I made this thing using Adobe Illustrator for the programming, which i divided up into two files because I did in fact use two different measurements of acrylic. For the batman logo itself, I used 9mm white acrylic and for the coin and the quote I used 3mm black acrylic. When i printed the two pieces using an Epilog Mini 18 Laser and successfully printed each piece, I then used acrylic glue to paste them together. The 9mm piece should stick out of the whole structure.

author: jsirgado

description.text: I made this to hold my rings.

1) I made this project in inventor
2) I created a new sketch, and made circle. The, I extruded it to about 0.25 inches
3) Then, I made another smaller circle on top of the previous one and extruded it to 3 inches
4) After, I made circles on the pole, extruded them inwards, and deleted them to make the holes on the pole the same size as the poles i was sticking in them.
5) I used the revolution tool to make a sphere on top.
6) Isaved my project as an STL.
7) I was ready to print on the makerbot, so I had to generate a G code
8) Finally, I printed to pole
9) When it was done i just cut wooden poles to 1.5 inches and stuck them in the holes.

title: Mendelmax 3 X axis motor protector and stabilizer.

description.text:
Just finished building my shiny new Mendelmax 3. The way the X axis motor hangs off the side of that 20x60 rail from a piece of laser cut steel made me sad, aesthetically, It just looked a little ghetto considering how nice the rest of the printer is.   
So I made a little shell to go around it to add a generally more stylish look, and to help protect that sheet steel mount from any overzealous belt tightening on my part.   
It probably isn't necessary, but it assuages my anxiety about it and I think it looks pretty cool. There is a gap to permit wiring in case you are running the motor cables through the 20x60 rail like I did.
Print it. Grab a couple m5-8's and some rail nuts. Do it up.

comments.text: I was just thinking of designing one myself, but you saved the the trouble. I been having backlash issues and I don't like how that stepper wiggles on the flimsy metal. You don't by chance have something like this for the Y axis?
comments.author: senormeow

comments.text: Thanks. Unfortunately I haven't really dug in on the Y axis to stabilize that nasty thin plate. I probably should as I Still see mt have problems printing stuff that is round properly and something is causing it. I tighten the everliving crap out of the belts and can't figure it out still a year later.
comments.author: senormeow

description.text:
This is a geared extruder for the SmartRap designed by modifying  @Mak-a-face's excellent E3D V5 Compact extruder, and using two gears made by @AlmeidaJuan.  
Please ignore the excessive amount of washers, I don't know where I got the hobbed bolt I'm using in the picture but the distance from the head is ridiculous.
You'll need to either make a hole in the wooden base or put the assembly on the back edge in order for the hobbed bolt to fit (see first picture).

title: Thing9
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is a tower-like thing. That extra support thing kind of looks like a leg. In fact, it almost looks like the whole thing is crawling through that hole in the wall. This one gave me a lot of trouble printing, mostly in the transition area from the "trunk" to the "top". Even though the overhang is only 45 degrees, I have been getting a lot of drooping printing in PLA. I think I just need more airflow to cool it. I would expect fewer problems in ABS. In addition to Thing9, I made Thing9Top to experiment with printing that feature. It doesn't look bad on its own, so I'm including it below. Dimensions:
Thing9: 59.2mm x 57.6mm x 102.6mm tall
Thing9Top: 26.0mm x 26.0mm x 57.1mm tall I did learn two interesting things about my printer (RapMan 3.0) from multiple attempts at printing this, both pretty obvious in hindsight. Printing Thing9Top gave different results, in the same areas, than Thing9, just due to the height above the print plate. When the print head is low, the air from the fan blows down and across the plate, cooling the print well. When the head is high, like near the top of Thing9, the RapMan's fan produces much less horizontal airflow. Also, since the fan is positioned on one side of the extruder, cooling is much greater on that side. The "spokes" on that side turned out perfect, while those on the opposite side drooped. I saw the same effect previously while printing a dodecahedron, but didn't figure out why. These effects don't matter if you don't use a fan while printing, but I thought it would be worth mentioning them for the few that do. Also, it is easier to blame my printer than the 3D model ;).

comments.text: this is beautiful. It really catches people's eye as they walk by my desk. Im still calibrating my new budget Prusa I3 and this printed great. The roof is very easy to print becasue its a cone around 45* so the printer just 'spirals' the whole thing. Turned out fantastic on default setting with pla.

Boscam FR632 is a nice diversity video receiver. I wanted to mount it in a semi-permanent way while maintaining the possibility to move it. I am not a great fan of slapping Velcro to my equipment, so I designed a custom holder instead. The yellow line close to the bottom was an experiment. I wanted to add some variation to the looks of the holder. The line is not part of the STL file and the print does not require dual extruders.
To make the line I just paused the print, switched to yellow filament, printed for a while and then switched back to black. Quite easy, I will use the technique again.

title: 23 mm to 30 mm microscope eyepiece adaptor

description.text:
The stereo zoom microscope I recently bought came with 30 mm diameter eyepieces. I also bought another set of eyepieces but these were 23mm diameter.
So I designed the attached converter so that the 23 mm diameter eyepieces would fit in the microscope.
There will be shrinkage due to the nature of whatever filament is used - mine were made with ABS. The outer diameter fit the microscope well, the inner diameter had to be sand papered to fit. A cylindrical piece of sand paper works well to increase the inner diameter.The bonus is that sand papering made an exact snug fit on the 23mm diameter eyepieces.

These were printed on a DaVinci XYZ printer.
0.3 mm layer height
90% solid
Normal shells
Standard speed
No rafts, no supports
It took about 43 minutes to print 2.
